front.title: Prevent Premature Interactive Connectivity Establishment (ICE) Failures

section.title: Introduction

t.xref: describes a protocol, Interactive Connectivity Establishment (ICE), for Network Address Translator (NAT) traversal for UDP-based communication.

section.t: When an endpoint receives the initial set of candidates from the remote peer, it starts to process them. As part of the processing, one or more candidates might get discarded. There are a number of reasons why a candidate is discared, e.g., because it represents an IP version that is not supported by the endpoint, or if the connection-address associated with the candidate is represented by a Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) that the endpoint is not able to resolve. Similairly, as a candidate by definition represents a single connection-address, if a FQDN resoles into multiple connection-addresses the associated candidate needs to be discared.
NOTE: Future specifications might describe how FQDNs that resolve into multiple connection-addresses are used with ICE.

According to the procedures in , if an endpoint discards the complete set of initial candidates received from the remote peer, it will declare an ICE failure, and terminate the session establishment, as the endpoint's list of remote candidates will be empty.

Once the endpoints have exchanged the initial set of candidates, and start performing connectivity cheks, additional candidiates might be created as a result of the connectivity checks. Such candidates are referred to as peer relexive candidates. However, the endpoint will most likely have declared ICE failure before it is able to create such candidates.

This speicifcation updates , by suggesting that an endpoint does not immediately declare ICE failure in case the initial set of candidiates received from the remote peer are discarded, but instead wait for a while in case it will receive connectivity checks that create one or more peer reflexive candidates. Once the endpoint has created such candidates, it processes them using the normal procedures defined in .

section.title: Conventions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The security considerations for ICE are defined in . This specification only recommends ICE endpoints to wait for a certain time of period before they declare ICE failure, and does not introduce new security considerations.
